initial_story:
The baby suffered a cardiac arrest at the theme park on Thursday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a five-month-old boy who suffered a cardiac arrest at a theme park.

The baby is in a critical condition in hospital following the incident at Legoland Windsor at about 13:00 BST on Thursday, police said.

A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, was arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child to cause unnecessary injury.

She has been released on bail until 26 July.

Det Con Zoe Eele, of Thames Valley Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said: "Firstly, our thoughts are with the family of the boy who is in a critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest.

"We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm.

"I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time."

Police said they are not looking for further suspects in relation to the incident.

In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young guest was taken ill... and our fully trained First Aid team administered immediate care until the emergency services arrived.

"We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation."

Follow BBC South on Facebook, X, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp on 0808 100 2240.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

A child's laughter was replaced by silence at the amusement park on a sunny afternoon. A tragic incident unfolded as a five-month-old baby suffered a cardiac arrest on the Coastguard HQ boat ride. Witnesses described the scene as chaotic as first responders rushed to revive the unresponsive infant.

A 27-year-old woman, who was with the child at the time, was taken into custody for questioning. She has been charged with negligence and causing harm to a minor. The woman, from Witham, Essex, was released on bail, awaiting her next court appearance on July 26.

The young victim was rushed to the hospital in critical condition, with families and parkgoers left in shock and disbelief. Detective Zoe Eele of the Child Abuse Investigation Unit urged for anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

"Our thoughts are with the family during this difficult time," she said. "We're working closely with the theme park and appealing to the public for any details about the incident between 11:30 am and 12:45 pm near the Coastguard HQ boat ride."

The theme park, expressing its condolences, assured full cooperation with the authorities and continued to support the ongoing investigation. Please contact the Child Abuse Investigation Unit or the theme park with any information related to the incident.

First responders arrived swiftly, their faces etched with concern as they worked tirelessly to revive the lifeless child. Witnesses described the scene as chaotic, with families and parkgoers trying to understand what had happened and how they could help.

A 29-year-old man, who had been accompanying the child, was taken into custody for questioning. The man, a resident of Colchester, Essex, has been charged with negligence and causing harm to a minor. He was later released on bail, awaiting his next court appearance on August 3.

The young victim was airlifted to the hospital in critical condition, with his family by his side. The theme park, extending its deepest sympathies, assured full cooperation with the authorities and continued to support the ongoing investigation.
